awd_titl_txt: Support for the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides the U.S. membership contribution toward core support for the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA) for calendar years 2016-2020. IIASA is an independent, non-governmental, international research institution devoted to interdisciplinary, policy-oriented research.  It is located in Laxenburg, Austria. Its research agenda focuses on systems approaches to the analysis of the interconnected and interdependent challenges raised by global transformations in the environmental, economic, technological and societal spheres.  IIASA offers a neutral venue for conceiving and analyzing strategies for cooperative action on common problems in a globalized, rapidly transforming world.  IIASA is supported by a network of nongovernmental National Member Organizations (NMOs) in 23 countries.

IIASA's Research Plan for 2016-2020 describes nine research programs:  Advanced Systems Analysis (ASA); Air Quality and Greenhouse Gases (AIR); Ecosystem Services and Management (ESM); Energy (ENE); Evolution and Ecology (EEP); Risk and Resilience (RAR); Transitions to New Technologies (TNT); Water (WAT); and World Population (POP).

NSF Project Outcomes Report for IIASA from 2021 to 2022

This project provided the United States membership contribution towards core support for the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA) from 1 June 2021 to 31 May 2022. IIASA is an international research institute that conducts policy-oriented research into global change issues that are too large or complex to be solved by a single country or academic discipline. This includes pressing concerns that affect all of humanity, such as climate change, food security, and sustainable development.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of IIASA research activities lies in its innovative use of systems analysis to identify policy solutions to current and emerging sustainability challenges. The high quality of the institute?s work is demonstrated through its publication record, the worldwide interest in joint IIASA-USA research collaborations (see Figure 1), and the institute?s world-class research models, tools, and data. Peer-reviewed journal articles were up by 60% in 2021 compared to 2015, and those in high-impact journals grew by 100% over the same period. IIASA open science policies, in place since 2016, ensure the knowledge generated and a growing number of research tools are freely available to all.

Figure 1. A co-authorship network analysis over time of joint IIASA-USA publications between 2021 and 2022. Austria and the USA are implicated in all data points and therefore not mapped separately (Source: Scopus. Tool: VOS Viewer, threshold 5).

Figure 2. A keyword network analysis of joint IIASA-USA publications between 2021 and 2022. The three main themes of joint research are climate change (red), sustainable development (green), and population (blue). (Source: Scopus. Tool: VOS Viewer, threshold 15).

IIASA ensured continuous innovation between 2021 and 2022 by taking advantage of the latest technologies, including agent-based modeling, artificial intelligence, and machine learning, to create new and improved systems analysis tools for increased impact. Intellectual advances have enabled more sophisticated computer models to explore new questions, such as how to apply agent-based models to analyze national economies; how to simultaneously tackle biodiversity loss and climate change without threatening food or water security; how to dramatically improve air quality over major population centers; and credible strategies to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions while avoiding temperature overshoot.

Significant progress was made into new research methods that have produced novel insights into emerging global challenges. These include what is driving the growing amount of climate-induced migration, the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on energy demand, and the role international trade can play in promoting sustainable development.

IIASA has pioneered new approaches to continually improve the quality of data and inputs that underpin systems analysis. These range from engaging over 15,000 citizen scientists to provide near real-time and accurate environmental monitoring of the Earth?s surface through participatory processes with multiple stakeholders, and to involve citizens in finding long-lasting solutions to the impacts of global change at their local or regional level.  

 

Broader Impacts

Broader impacts are inherent in the IIASA research strategy and through this project, IIASA research benefited society in four broad ways:

  • Provided evidence-based policy advice to multilateral negotiations on climate change and biodiversity. For example, IIASA researchers played a leading role in mapping credible pathways to limiting global warming to 1.5˚C above pre-industrial levels and are making important contributions to the Global Biodiversity Framework (2022).
  • Trained over 400 early-career researchers in systems analysis through programs for advanced graduate students (YSSP Program) and postdoctoral scholars, along with foundational courses in systems analysis and training courses on IIASA models.
  • Offered a neutral venue for international scientific collaboration on shared global sustainability challenges, which in turn promotes co-operation between nations. For instance, IIASA brought together hundreds of experts to use systems thinking to chart pathways to achieve sustainability by 2050 (TWI2050) and identify how best to build a more resilient, sustainable, and just recovery to the COVID-19 pandemic.
  • In 2022, IIASA celebrates its 50th anniversary by convening over 1,060 stakeholders of the global systems analysis community through events in 12 member countries. One of these events was hosted at the Boston University Pardee School of Global Studies and focused on the pioneering role of IIASA as an instrument of science diplomacy.

Collaboration between US and IIASA scientists between 2021 and 2022 included 219 US research institutions and universities working on 308 peer-reviewed publications with IIASA authors. Many of these publications are highly cited with 15 cited over 50 times, and one publication cited over 490 times.

Policymakers find IIASA systems thinking invaluable in informing policies, particularly those that systematically and comprehensively aim to reduce footprints and enhance the resilience of natural and socioeconomic systems in pursuit of a sustainable future. In total, 132 US policy documents cited IIASA research in areas ranging from energy technologies to population aging to water futures and climate change.
